 This is certainly true in Australia, a friend of mine was the no.1 graduating student studying Education in Australia, he had a UAI of 90, which means he was in the 10th percentile of the graduating year overall. The minimum cutoff to get into most science/law/engineering/business subjects will be 90 if not 95 or 99+ at more popular unis, so I don't know where Jo gets the idea that doing one of the easiest subjects and jobs available to an adult, both intellectually and physically, somehow makes you the cream of the crop.
 
 I'm sure some teachers have a genuine passion to teach, or at least a passion for the structured prison-like environment of the school where ringing bells tell them what to do, but the majority simply fall into it because they are too incompetent or lazy to do anybody else.  In the end, it's worth considering whether sending your child to a government school should be considered child abuse.

Jo Bennett

Most (secondary) teachers in the UK didn't study education as their undergraduate subject. They studied their academic subject (Maths and Physics in my case) and did a postgraduate teaching qualification. I assure you that the requirements for my undergraduate degree were just as stringent as everyone elses. You can do undergraduate courses that include Qualified Teaching Status but you still (for secondary courses) spend most of your time studying your chosen subject. Entry requirements for courses vary enormously regardless of subject. I can find you maths courses that require a C, D and E at A-Level, that doesn't make mathematicians thick.
 
 @ Symbiote: As for teaching being easy, you've clearly never done it. There aren't many professional jobs where you are expected to be on your feet and moving for most of the day, and if the intellectual (and emotional) demands were low don't you think more people would stick with it? Nationally in England 50% drop out within 3 years of qualifying. Of my friends who trained to be a teachers (many of them with Masters degrees in their chosen subjects), I'm the only one who is currently in a teaching post. It's a tough job. If it's so easy I'm puzzled as to why you aren't having a go yourself.

 Their reasons were nothing to do with lack of challenge, and a lot to do with workload and stress, and the behaviour of some students.
 
 

 I don't want to be a public school teacher for much the same reason I don't want to be a prison guard at Guantanamo Bay, I don't consider it ethical to take on that kind of role even if it is a guarantee for a comfortable, secure, life where you don't really have to think.

 
 Far more likely you wouldn't last a day in a classroom, you certainly wouldn't if you try and do it without thinking.
jyoshu

It is an occupation populated by elderly obese women with arthritis, so I don't take the complaint about having to stand for 4 hours a day very seriously.
 
 Lack of challenge is for many people a reason to leave a jobs, so no, I'm not at all surprised that the more intelligent teachers quickly leave. Perhaps your point would be better served if your masters qualified friends remained, and the less educated teachers resigned because it was too hard for them?

 
 I can't agree with a number of things you said here. I commend teachers for being willing to impart an education to kids. As we've covered in another thread, I do think that needs to be limited as much as possible to academic matters and not moralistic ones, but I think you're wrong if you think that teaching is an easy occupation.
JPSartre12

I can't agree with a number of things you said here. I commend teachers for being willing to impart an education to kids. As we've covered in another thread, I do think that needs to be limited as much as possible to academic matters and not moralistic ones, but I think you're wrong if you think that teaching is an easy occupation.

 
 As with many jobs, the devil is in the details. What age student? What subject matter? what school district? All of these are important in determining the ease of the job.
Jo Bennett

As with many jobs, the devil is in the details. What age student? What subject matter? what school district? All of these are important in determining the ease of the job.

 
 From what I gather from talking to teachers in other schools, different schools have different challenges, it would be hard to put a finger on whether the school where you're at risk of being attacked daily is more difficult than one where the volume of work completed creates a marking load in the hours every day. Similarly primary school teachers may not have the behaviour issues that secondary teachers have to deal with, but they constantly teach mixed ability classes in subjects with which they are not overly confident. How difficult you find these competing challenges is largely down to temperament, but I've not met anyone who has done it who thinks the job is easy.
JPSartre12

From what I gather from talking to teachers in other schools, different schools have different challenges, it would be hard to put a finger on whether the school where you're at risk of being attacked daily is more difficult than one where the volume of work completed creates a marking load in the hours every day. Similarly primary school teachers may not have the behaviour issues that secondary teachers have to deal with, but they constantly teach mixed ability classes in subjects with which they are not overly confident. How difficult you find these competing challenges is largely down to temperament, but I've not met anyone who has done it who thinks the job is easy.

 
 Here in the States, teachers don't typically have undergrad degrees in the subject matter that they teach. A teacher has an education degree, not a BS in Science, Math, etc., so they aren't required to take the more challenging core curricula that we scientists have to. As a result, many people that go to college take the easiest curricula just to "get a degree" and amongst the easiest degrees to get is an education degree. 
 Maybe the fact that UK teachers have undergrad degrees in subject matter in addition to education credentials says something about why US schools can't compete with the rest of the world's education system...until the college level, that is.
